timeline.bodyText: (Just an observation): this replaces google's deprecated Objects.equal with the java.util.Objects one. 👍
timeline.author: Jolyon-S

replies.bodyText: I'll write an automated refactor from this guava method to j.u.Objects later today
replies.author: carterkozak

timeline.author: Jolyon-S

replies.bodyText:
This change should be safe, if the strings are equal (either both null or string-wise equal), both the before and after here would end up returning true. I added a unit test that shows this and passes both before and after.
I think that comment applies to optionsMapsFunctionallyEqual.
replies.author: schlosna

timeline.author: Jolyon-S

replies.bodyText: there was a unicode non-breaking space that the javadoc compiler was complaining about that I converted to a standard ASCII space
replies.author: schlosna

timeline.bodyText: I'm curious as to why you switched these around - there is a null check directly above which ensures that we don't call .equals on a null.
timeline.author: Jolyon-S

replies.bodyText: mostly just habit of yoda conditions
replies.author: schlosna

timeline.bodyText: It looks like the difference here is that you'll return false if the clientIds are different (where before, if I understand this correctly, just if the references are the same). Presumably the clientId is supposed to uniquely identify a client, but I haven't dug into the code to verify this.
timeline.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.message:
Fix non-ASCII character error

Resolves following error from non-breaking space in JavaDoc

atlasdb-commons/src/main/java/com/palantir/common/time/Clock.java:23: error: unmappable character (0xC2) for encoding US-ASCII
atlasdb-commons/src/main/java/com/palantir/common/time/Clock.java:23: error: unmappable character (0xA0) for encoding US-ASCII
Fix ReferenceEquality in generated stream store code
Rendered stream store prefers collection constructors
